results.title: Rhapsody in August = Hachigatsu no kyshikyoku
results.creator_credit: Akira Kurosawa, Hisao Kurosawa and Kurosawa Productions
results.brief_description: In this moving and thought-provoking film, four Japanese teenagers begin a voyage of discovery when their parents travel to Hawaii leaving them in the care of their grandmother, Kane. The elderly woman painfully recalls the death of her husband, and the horrors inflicted on the Japanese people when the atomic bomb was dropped on Nagasaki during World War II. Through her recollections her grandchildren learn the importance of remembering the past and of placing blame on war itself as opposed to the foreigners who waged it. It is a lesson that is challenged when her Japanese-American nephew arrives from America. His attitudes and opinions reveal that the relationship between Japan and America is far more complicated than a simple matter of understanding and forgiveness. Kurosawa’s subject here is the process of memory and commemoration, played out by different generations of Japanese on both the personal and social levels. Cast includes Richard Gere, Sachiko Murase, Hisashi Igawa and Narumi Kayashima.

results.title: Rex: Alienated youth
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Social Security”.
Rex left home at 16 after an argument with his father and now finds that he’s left with the choice of life on the dole or continuing menial work. The film examines the life Rex leads and the sorts of options open to him, none of them in the area Rex is really interested in. One in a series of films made originally for daytime television panel discussions to introduce the public to the range of social services available form the government. No other credits available.

results.title: Rewind, tape 2 eps. 14-26
results.creator_credit: Margaret Murphy, SBS Independent, National Film and Sound Archive of Australia and Film Australia
results.brief_description: A series of entertaining 5-minute history bytes narrated by Jack Thompson. Using newsreels, documentaries, home movies, television and cinema advertisements, each segment presents a snapshot of the evolution of everyday Australian life, attitudes and habits through the twentieth century. The segments are grouped around the six themes of “Rituals”, “Leisure”, ‘Rights and responsibilities”, “Environment”, “Building a society” and “Changing ways”. Tape Two contains episodes 14-26. They are entitled: “Fighting nature”, “Law of this land”, “Horse power”, “Your attention is requested”, “Sea around us”, “Dress sense”, “Great prospects”, “Making Australia home”, “Frozen images”, “A Fair Go”, “To be or not to be”, “Suburban dreams” and “A call to arms”.

results.title: Rewards and reinforcements
results.creator_credit: Robert E. Gilbert, Lee Myerson and Kismet Films
results.brief_description: Economically underprivileged children must often be provided with motives for learning. Because the value system of these children may differ from that of the economically satisfied child, behaviour may need to be reinforced with rewards such as sweets, money, clothes, or other material objects. This principle of reinforcement is based on the operant conditioning theory and involves the application of immediate rewards to shape gradually more difficult tasks.

results.title: Revolution of necessity
results.creator_credit: Christopher McCullough, Robert Raymond and Opus Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Out of the fiery furnace”.
The discovery of how to turn coke into fuel launches the Industrial Revolution. The need for better pumps in the mines eventually leads to the steam engine, which together with the railway transforms society. Bessemer’s converter gives the world cheap steel.

results.title: Revolution's orphans
results.creator_credit: John Smith, Roman Kroitor and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: In 1956 the Hungarian Revolution claimed 50,000 lives. Clara and her father were two refugees who came to Canada to settle, fleeing the treachery of the secret police. Both were haunted by the events they had experienced. It takes the arrival of Clara’s Uncle Janos from Budapest to explain to her the years of uncertainty and bitterness she had lived through since her childhood escape.

results.title: Revolting Rhymes
results.brief_description: In this animated film, Roald Dahl, the master of comic stories for children retells the stories of “Snow White”, “Jack and the beanstalk”, “Little Red Riding Hood”, “The three little pigs”, “Goldilocks and the three bears” and “Cinderella” introducing colourful and amusing twists to these well known stories. The animation is based on the original illustrations by Quentin Blake.
